abstract.para: As a regular user, you can run any command as &rootuser; by adding &sudo; before it. This prompts you to provide the &rootuser; password. If authenticated successfully, this runs the command as &rootuser;.

topic.para: When running a command prefaced with &sudo;, the system asks you for the password of the &rootuser; account. After successful authentication, the command is executed with superuser privileges.

Depending on the &sudo; configuration, the elevated privileges persist for a certain period of time and as long as you are working in the same terminal session. So you do not need to provide the &rootuser; password again when running another &sudo; command.
